categories.name: Psychology: Tendencies & Biases
categories.description: Munger's 25 standard causes of human misjudgment plus extended biases

categories.name: Thinking Tools & Meta-Frameworks
categories.description: Methods for better reasoning and decision-making

categories.name: Business: Competitive Advantage & Moats
categories.description: Durable competitive advantages and market dynamics

thinkers.name: Ray Dalio
key_works: Principles for Dealing with the Changing World Order

models.name: Reward and Punishment Superresponse Tendency
models.description: People respond intensely to incentives, both positive and negative. Never think about something else when you should be thinking about incentives.

failure_modes.name: Incentive Blindness
failure_modes.description: Failing to identify hidden or non-obvious incentives that drive behavior
prevention_strategies: Map all stakeholders and their incentives
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyst concludes executives are aligned with shareholders based only on stock options, missing that vesting schedules encourage short-term manipulation

failure_modes.name: Incentive Oversimplification
failure_modes.description: Reducing complex multi-incentive situations to a single dominant incentive
prevention_strategies: Always identify at least 3 incentives per actor
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming salespeople only respond to commission, missing that peer recognition and job security also drive behavior

failure_modes.name: Incentive Timing Mismatch
failure_modes.description: Ignoring the temporal dimension of incentives - when rewards/punishments are delivered matters
failure_modes.example_scenario: Designing a bonus structure with annual payouts when quarterly behavior changes are needed

failure_modes.name: Perverse Incentive Creation
failure_modes.description: Proposed solutions inadvertently create incentives for undesired behavior
prevention_strategies: Apply inversion - how could this be gamed?
Review historical examples of similar incentives
failure_modes.example_scenario: Paying bounties for dead cobras leads to cobra farming (the original Cobra Effect)

failure_modes.name: Incentive Magnitude Miscalibration
failure_modes.description: Incentives too weak to change behavior or so strong they cause dysfunction
failure_modes.example_scenario: Offering a 1% bonus for safety improvements when workers can earn 20% more by cutting corners

safeguards: Apply inversion - how could this be gamed?
Map all stakeholders and their incentives
Review historical examples of similar incentives
Always identify at least 3 incentives per actor

models.name: Liking/Loving Tendency
models.description: We tend to distort facts to favor people and things we like or love, ignoring faults and complying with wishes.

failure_modes.name: Affinity Bias Blindspot
failure_modes.description: Failing to recognize when liking someone distorts objective analysis
prevention_strategies: Require independent review by someone without relationship
failure_modes.example_scenario: Investment committee approves deal because they like the founder, ignoring red flags in financials

failure_modes.name: Halo Effect Propagation
failure_modes.description: Positive feelings in one domain incorrectly spread to unrelated domains
prevention_strategies: Require evidence for each positive claim
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming a successful entrepreneur will also be a good board member without evidence of governance skills

failure_modes.name: Reciprocity Contamination
failure_modes.description: Liking someone because they did something nice, then distorting analysis to favor them
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyst gives favorable rating to company whose CEO invited them to exclusive event

failure_modes.name: In-Group Favoritism
failure_modes.description: Preferring analysis that favors people similar to oneself
failure_modes.example_scenario: Venture capitalists consistently funding founders from their own alma mater

failure_modes.name: Criticism Avoidance
failure_modes.description: Softening or omitting negative findings to preserve relationships
failure_modes.example_scenario: Auditor fails to flag issues because they want to maintain client relationship

failure_modes.description: Liking someone makes you ignore their flaws
failure_modes.real_world_case: Elizabeth Holmes - investors liked her, ignored red flags at Theranos.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If you can't name 3 flaws, you're probably biased

failure_modes.description: Promoting liked people over qualified ones
failure_modes.real_world_case: Family businesses failing due to unqualified family members in leadership.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Liked candidates should still meet 80% of objective criteria

failure_modes.description: Liking things associated with liked people
failure_modes.real_world_case: Celebrity endorsements - liking celebrity transfers to product regardless of quality.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Celebrity endorsement adds 0 information about product quality

failure_modes.description: Being manipulated by those who flatter you
failure_modes.real_world_case: CEOs surrounded by yes-men making poor decisions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If no one disagrees with you, you're not getting honest feedback

failure_modes.description: Favoring those similar to you
failure_modes.real_world_case: Homogeneous boards and teams missing diverse perspectives.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Teams with < 30% diversity underperform on complex problems

models.name: Disliking/Hating Tendency
models.description: We distort facts, ignore virtues, and dislike people associated with those we already dislike.

failure_modes.name: Negative Halo Effect
failure_modes.description: Dislike in one area spreads to unfairly negative assessment in unrelated areas
failure_modes.example_scenario: Dismissing a competitor's valid innovation because of personal dislike for their CEO

failure_modes.name: Guilt by Association
failure_modes.description: Negative judgment based on association rather than direct evidence
failure_modes.example_scenario: Rejecting a vendor because they also serve a competitor you dislike

failure_modes.name: Confirmation of Negative Priors
failure_modes.description: Seeking only information that confirms pre-existing negative views
failure_modes.example_scenario: Research report on competitor only cites negative reviews, ignoring positive customer feedback

failure_modes.name: Proportionality Distortion
failure_modes.description: Minor flaws magnified due to dislike, major positives minimized
failure_modes.example_scenario: Rejecting acquisition target for minor accounting issues while ignoring strong market position

failure_modes.name: Motivated Reasoning Against
failure_modes.description: Constructing elaborate justifications for negative conclusions driven by emotion
failure_modes.example_scenario: Building complex bear case for stock after losing money on previous investment in same sector

failure_modes.mode: Dismissing good ideas from disliked sources
failure_modes.description: Rejecting valid information because of who says it
failure_modes.real_world_case: Political polarization - dismissing opponent's valid points.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Good ideas are equally valid regardless of source

failure_modes.description: Seeking evidence to confirm negative views
failure_modes.real_world_case: Short sellers becoming blind to positive developments in hated companies.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If you can't name 3 positives about disliked entity, you're biased

failure_modes.description: Conflicts escalate due to mutual dislike
failure_modes.real_world_case: Business feuds destroying value for both parties.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Conflict costs typically exceed 'winning' benefits by 3-5x

failure_modes.description: Losing valuable people due to interpersonal dislike
failure_modes.real_world_case: Key employees leaving due to personality conflicts with leadership.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Replacing key talent costs 150-200% of annual salary

failure_modes.description: Missing opportunities in disliked sectors/companies
failure_modes.real_world_case: Value investors missing tech because they disliked the sector.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Disliked sectors can outperform for decades

models.name: Doubt-Avoidance Tendency
models.description: The brain is designed to remove doubt by reaching quick decisions, especially under stress.

failure_modes.name: Premature Closure
failure_modes.description: Reaching conclusions too quickly to eliminate uncomfortable uncertainty
failure_modes.example_scenario: CEO makes acquisition decision in one meeting to 'stop the uncertainty' without due diligence

failure_modes.name: False Certainty
failure_modes.description: Expressing high confidence to avoid acknowledging genuine uncertainty
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyst gives precise price target without acknowledging wide range of possible outcomes

failure_modes.name: Binary Thinking
failure_modes.description: Reducing complex situations to yes/no when reality is probabilistic
failure_modes.example_scenario: Framing market outlook as 'bull or bear' instead of probability distribution of outcomes

failure_modes.name: Anchoring on First Answer
failure_modes.description: Accepting first plausible explanation to resolve doubt quickly
failure_modes.example_scenario: Attributing sales decline to economy without considering product issues or competition

failure_modes.name: Stress-Induced Snap Judgment
failure_modes.description: Making quick decisions under stress to eliminate anxiety of uncertainty
failure_modes.example_scenario: Panic selling during market crash to eliminate anxiety of watching losses

failure_modes.description: Deciding too quickly to avoid uncertainty
failure_modes.real_world_case: Snap judgments in hiring leading to poor fits.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Important decisions should have minimum 24-hour delay

failure_modes.description: Claiming certainty that doesn't exist
failure_modes.real_world_case: Financial forecasts presented as certain when highly uncertain.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Most forecasts should have ±20% uncertainty ranges

failure_modes.description: Sticking with decisions to avoid doubt
failure_modes.real_world_case: Sunk cost fallacy - continuing failing projects to avoid admitting error.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Review major decisions quarterly with kill criteria

failure_modes.description: Accepting expert opinion to avoid own doubt
failure_modes.real_world_case: Following analyst recommendations without own analysis.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Expert consensus is wrong 30-40% of the time on complex issues

failure_modes.description: Forcing complex issues into yes/no to avoid doubt
failure_modes.real_world_case: Investment decisions as all-in or nothing, missing position sizing.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Most decisions have 5+ reasonable options, not just 2

models.name: Inconsistency-Avoidance Tendency
models.description: We resist changing our habits, beliefs, and conclusions once formed. The brain conserves programming space.

failure_modes.name: Sunk Cost Persistence
failure_modes.description: Continuing failed course of action to remain consistent with past decisions
prevention_strategies: Evaluate decisions fresh ignoring sunk costs
failure_modes.example_scenario: Continuing to fund failing project because 'we've already invested so much'

failure_modes.name: Belief Perseverance
failure_modes.description: Maintaining beliefs despite contradictory evidence to avoid inconsistency
prevention_strategies: Require thesis revision on new data
failure_modes.example_scenario: Maintaining bullish thesis on stock despite multiple earnings misses

failure_modes.name: Identity-Protective Cognition
failure_modes.description: Rejecting information that threatens self-concept or group identity
failure_modes.example_scenario: Value investor dismissing growth investing evidence because 'that's not who we are'

failure_modes.name: Commitment Escalation
failure_modes.description: Increasing commitment to justify past decisions rather than cutting losses
failure_modes.example_scenario: Doubling down on losing position to 'prove the original thesis right'

failure_modes.name: Cognitive Dissonance Resolution via Distortion
failure_modes.description: Distorting new information to fit existing beliefs rather than updating beliefs
failure_modes.example_scenario: Reinterpreting missed earnings as 'actually positive because expectations were too high'

failure_modes.description: Refusing to change views despite new evidence
failure_modes.real_world_case: Kodak leadership refusing to accept digital photography threat.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If you haven't changed a major view in 2 years, you're not learning

failure_modes.description: Small commitments leading to large ones
failure_modes.real_world_case: Gradual ethical compromises leading to fraud.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Small compromises compound - review trajectory quarterly

failure_modes.description: Views become part of identity, impossible to change
failure_modes.real_world_case: Political identity preventing objective policy evaluation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If changing view would feel like betrayal, it's identity-based

failure_modes.description: Appearing consistent even when wrong
failure_modes.real_world_case: Leaders doubling down on bad strategies to appear consistent.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Changing mind on evidence is strength, not weakness

failure_modes.description: Past decisions constraining future options unnecessarily
failure_modes.real_world_case: QWERTY keyboard - suboptimal but locked in by consistency.
warning_signs: We've always done it this way
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Review 'constraints' annually - many are self-imposed

models.name: Curiosity Tendency
models.description: Humans have a natural drive to seek knowledge and understanding, which can be cultivated.

failure_modes.name: Analysis Paralysis from Over-Curiosity
failure_modes.description: Endless information gathering without reaching actionable conclusions
failure_modes.example_scenario: Research team delays recommendation indefinitely because 'we need more data'

failure_modes.name: Curiosity Misdirection
failure_modes.description: Pursuing interesting but irrelevant tangents instead of core questions
failure_modes.example_scenario: Deep dive into company history when the key question is about future competitive position

failure_modes.name: Curiosity Deficit
failure_modes.description: Insufficient curiosity leading to surface-level analysis
failure_modes.example_scenario: Accepting management guidance without questioning underlying assumptions

failure_modes.name: Selective Curiosity
failure_modes.description: Being curious only about confirming information, not disconfirming
prevention_strategies: Equal research into bull and bear cases
failure_modes.example_scenario: Deep research into growth drivers but superficial look at competitive threats

failure_modes.name: Curiosity Without Synthesis
failure_modes.description: Gathering information without integrating it into coherent understanding
failure_modes.example_scenario: Report full of facts but no clear investment thesis or recommendation

failure_modes.description: Endless research preventing action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Academics who research forever but never publish or act.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 80% of value comes from first 20% of research

failure_modes.description: Learning that doesn't translate to action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Reading business books without implementing anything.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Learning without application has < 10% retention

failure_modes.description: Curiosity pulling attention from priorities
failure_modes.real_world_case: Entrepreneurs distracted by new ideas instead of executing current ones.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Switching costs are 20-30 minutes per context switch

failure_modes.description: Investigating trivia instead of important questions
failure_modes.real_world_case: Investors researching company trivia instead of key drivers.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 5 key questions drive 80% of decision quality

failure_modes.description: Using research to avoid difficult action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Researching investments instead of making them.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Time in market beats timing the market over 10+ years

safeguards: Equal research into bull and bear cases

models.name: Kantian Fairness Tendency
models.description: We expect fair exchanges and reciprocal behavior, and react strongly to perceived unfairness.

failure_modes.name: Fairness Projection
failure_modes.description: Assuming others share your fairness standards when they don't
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming competitor will maintain pricing discipline because 'it's the rational thing to do'

failure_modes.name: Fairness-Based Overreaction
failure_modes.description: Disproportionate response to perceived unfairness damaging own interests
failure_modes.example_scenario: Rejecting profitable deal because terms feel 'unfair' even though they're market standard

failure_modes.name: Fairness Definition Mismatch
failure_modes.description: Different parties have different definitions of fair, leading to conflict
failure_modes.example_scenario: Merger negotiation fails because parties have different views on 'fair' valuation methodology

failure_modes.name: Fairness Blindness to Power Dynamics
failure_modes.description: Expecting fair treatment when power imbalance makes it unlikely
failure_modes.example_scenario: Small supplier expecting fair treatment from dominant customer without contractual protections

failure_modes.name: Procedural vs. Outcome Fairness Confusion
failure_modes.description: Confusing fair process with fair outcome or vice versa
prevention_strategies: Accept that fair process can yield unfair outcomes
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming auction process guarantees fair price when bidders may collude

failure_modes.description: Choosing fair but suboptimal outcomes
failure_modes.real_world_case: Equal pay regardless of performance destroying incentives.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Performance-based systems outperform equal systems by 20-40%

failure_modes.description: Rejecting unfair but beneficial offers
failure_modes.real_world_case: Rejecting acquisition offers because terms feel unfair.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Any gain > 0 is better than no gain from spite

failure_modes.description: Being exploited through fairness appeals
failure_modes.real_world_case: Negotiations lost by anchoring on 'fair' split instead of value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Fair is often defined by whoever speaks first

failure_modes.description: Treating unequal things as equal for fairness
failure_modes.real_world_case: Giving equal time to unequal arguments in debates.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Equal treatment of unequal things is unfair

failure_modes.description: Fair process producing unfair outcomes
failure_modes.real_world_case: Meritocracy that ignores starting point inequality.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Fair process with unfair outcomes is still unfair

failure_modes.description: Expecting fairness where it doesn't exist
failure_modes.real_world_case: Expecting markets to be fair.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: World is less fair than we expect

failure_modes.description: Not acting because it's 'not fair'
failure_modes.real_world_case: Not negotiating because 'it should be fair'.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Waiting for fairness = waiting forever

failure_modes.description: Punishing unfairness at own cost
failure_modes.real_world_case: Rejecting unfair offers even when beneficial.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Fairness retaliation often costs more than accepting

failure_modes.description: Assuming others share fairness values
failure_modes.real_world_case: Being exploited by those who don't play fair.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Not everyone plays fair - protect yourself

failure_modes.description: Using fairness to avoid difficult decisions
failure_modes.real_world_case: Not firing poor performers because 'it's not fair'.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Fair process ≠ equal outcomes

models.name: Envy/Jealousy Tendency
models.description: Envy drives much human behavior and is often underestimated as a motivating force.

failure_modes.name: Envy-Driven Analysis Distortion
failure_modes.description: Negative analysis of successful competitors driven by envy rather than facts
failure_modes.example_scenario: Dismissing competitor's success as 'luck' or 'unsustainable' without evidence

failure_modes.name: Keeping Up with Joneses
failure_modes.description: Making decisions based on what others are doing rather than own situation
prevention_strategies: Focus on own situation and goals
failure_modes.example_scenario: Entering market because competitor did, without independent assessment of fit

failure_modes.name: Envy Blindness
failure_modes.description: Failing to recognize envy as a factor in own or others' behavior
prevention_strategies: Consider envy as explanation for behavior
failure_modes.example_scenario: Not understanding why board member opposes CEO's plan (envy of CEO's success)

failure_modes.name: Relative vs. Absolute Performance Confusion
failure_modes.description: Focusing on relative performance vs. peers instead of absolute returns
failure_modes.example_scenario: Feeling bad about 15% return because peers made 20%, ignoring that 15% meets goals

failure_modes.name: Schadenfreude-Driven Misjudgment
failure_modes.description: Pleasure in others' failures leading to underestimation of their recovery
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming struggling competitor will fail completely, missing their successful turnaround

failure_modes.description: Spending based on others' consumption
failure_modes.real_world_case: Lifestyle inflation destroying wealth accumulation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Comparison spending can reduce savings rate by 50%+

failure_modes.description: Chasing returns others have achieved
failure_modes.real_world_case: FOMO buying at market tops after seeing others' gains.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Performance chasing reduces returns by 2-4% annually

failure_modes.description: Undermining others due to envy
failure_modes.real_world_case: Workplace politics destroying team performance.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Toxic envy can reduce team performance by 30-50%

failure_modes.description: Focusing on what others have, ignoring own blessings
failure_modes.real_world_case: Wealthy people unhappy because others are wealthier.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Hedonic adaptation means more never feels like enough

failure_modes.description: Choosing careers based on others' success
failure_modes.real_world_case: Following hot careers without fit, leading to burnout.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Career fit matters more than prestige for long-term success

failure_modes.description: Being unhappy due to others' success
failure_modes.real_world_case: Unhappy despite success because others have more.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Comparison is the thief of joy

failure_modes.description: Making decisions to match others
failure_modes.real_world_case: Buying things to keep up with neighbors.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Envy-driven decisions are usually bad

failure_modes.description: Pleasure in others' misfortune clouding judgment
failure_modes.real_world_case: Celebrating competitor failure instead of improving.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Time spent on others = time not spent on self

failure_modes.description: Undermining others due to envy
failure_modes.real_world_case: Office politics driven by jealousy.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Sabotage costs more than it gains

failure_modes.description: Disguising envy as principled objection
failure_modes.real_world_case: Criticizing successful people for 'wrong' reasons.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Much criticism is disguised envy

models.name: Reciprocation Tendency
models.description: We feel obligated to repay favors and concessions, even when unsolicited.

failure_modes.name: Reciprocity Manipulation Blindness
failure_modes.description: Failing to recognize when favors are given to manipulate future decisions
failure_modes.example_scenario: Vendor provides expensive gifts before contract renewal negotiation

failure_modes.name: Disproportionate Reciprocation
failure_modes.description: Returning favors far exceeding the original favor's value
failure_modes.example_scenario: Approving large contract because vendor bought lunch

failure_modes.name: Negative Reciprocity Escalation
failure_modes.description: Tit-for-tat retaliation spiraling into destructive conflict
failure_modes.example_scenario: Price war escalating because each side retaliates against the other's cuts

failure_modes.name: Reciprocity Expectation Mismatch
failure_modes.description: Expecting reciprocation that others don't feel obligated to provide
failure_modes.example_scenario: Expecting referrals after providing free consulting, but client doesn't feel obligated

failure_modes.name: Concession Reciprocity Exploitation
failure_modes.description: Being manipulated by door-in-the-face technique (large request then smaller one)
prevention_strategies: Don't feel obligated by others' concessions
failure_modes.example_scenario: Agreeing to unfavorable terms because they're 'better' than initial outrageous ask

failure_modes.description: Being influenced by gifts or favors
failure_modes.real_world_case: Pharmaceutical company gifts influencing doctor prescriptions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Even small gifts ($10) measurably influence decisions

failure_modes.description: Revenge cycles destroying value
failure_modes.real_world_case: Business feuds escalating to mutual destruction.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Revenge typically costs more than the original harm

failure_modes.description: Others exploiting your reciprocation tendency
failure_modes.real_world_case: Free samples creating purchase obligation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Unsolicited favors create no genuine obligation

failure_modes.description: Returning more than received
failure_modes.real_world_case: Giving expensive gifts in response to small favors.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Reciprocation should be roughly proportional

failure_modes.description: Building up obligations that constrain future action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Political favors creating compromising obligations.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Favor debts compound - clear them quickly

failure_modes.description: Being manipulated through gifts/favors
failure_modes.real_world_case: Pharmaceutical reps giving gifts to doctors.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Small gifts create large obligations

failure_modes.description: Tit-for-tat escalating conflicts
failure_modes.real_world_case: Business disputes escalating to mutual destruction.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Negative reciprocity often escalates 2-3x

failure_modes.description: Accumulating obligations without realizing
failure_modes.real_world_case: Owing favors that compromise independence.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Obligations compound like interest

failure_modes.description: Expecting reciprocity that doesn't come
failure_modes.real_world_case: Helping others expecting help back.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 30-50% of favors are not reciprocated

failure_modes.description: Being manipulated by fake concessions
failure_modes.real_world_case: Door-in-face technique in negotiations.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Concession technique increases compliance 50%+

safeguards: Don't feel obligated by others' concessions

models.name: Influence-from-Mere-Association Tendency
models.description: We are influenced by associations, both positive and negative, even when logically irrelevant.

failure_modes.name: Messenger-Message Conflation
failure_modes.description: Judging information quality by who delivers it rather than content
failure_modes.example_scenario: Accepting investment thesis because it comes from famous investor without independent analysis

failure_modes.name: Past Success Association
failure_modes.description: Assuming future success because of association with past success
failure_modes.example_scenario: Investing in new fund because manager's previous fund succeeded, without analyzing why

failure_modes.name: Negative Association Contamination
failure_modes.description: Rejecting good ideas because associated with disliked source
failure_modes.example_scenario: Rejecting valid criticism because it comes from a competitor

failure_modes.name: Brand/Prestige Halo
failure_modes.description: Overvaluing things associated with prestigious brands or institutions
failure_modes.example_scenario: Paying premium for McKinsey advice without evaluating if it's better than alternatives

failure_modes.name: Temporal Association Error
failure_modes.description: Assuming causation from temporal association (post hoc ergo propter hoc)
failure_modes.example_scenario: Attributing stock rise to new CEO when it was driven by market-wide rally

failure_modes.description: Blaming bearer of bad news
failure_modes.real_world_case: Executives punishing those who report problems, hiding issues.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Organizations that shoot messengers fail 3x more often

failure_modes.description: Positive view of things associated with liked things
failure_modes.real_world_case: Stanford dropout founders getting funded based on school association.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Prestigious associations add noise, not signal

failure_modes.description: Negative view based on associations
failure_modes.real_world_case: Good companies avoided because of industry association.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Individual quality varies widely within any category

failure_modes.description: Automatic responses to associated stimuli
failure_modes.real_world_case: Buying on good news, selling on bad news without analysis.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Automatic responses are wrong 40-60% of the time

failure_modes.description: Judging based on past associations that no longer apply
failure_modes.real_world_case: Avoiding reformed companies based on past problems.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Reassess associations every 2-3 years

failure_modes.description: One positive trait influencing perception of all traits
failure_modes.real_world_case: Attractive people assumed to be competent.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Halo effect biases 30-50% of judgments

failure_modes.description: Negative associations spreading unfairly
failure_modes.real_world_case: Messenger blamed for bad news.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Bad news bearers are blamed 70%+ of time

failure_modes.description: Being influenced by brand associations
failure_modes.real_world_case: Paying premium for brand without substance.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Brand premium often exceeds value difference

failure_modes.description: Being influenced by celebrity endorsements
failure_modes.real_world_case: Buying products because celebrities endorse.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Celebrity endorsements increase sales 20-50%

failure_modes.description: Assuming past success predicts future success
failure_modes.real_world_case: Hiring from successful companies assuming competence.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Past success is weak predictor of future success

models.name: Simple, Pain-Avoiding Psychological Denial
models.description: We deny reality when it is too painful to accept, distorting facts to reduce psychological pain.

failure_modes.name: Reality Denial Detection Failure
failure_modes.description: Failing to recognize when analysis is avoiding painful truths
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analysis avoids discussing possibility that core business is in terminal decline

failure_modes.name: Gradual Decline Denial
failure_modes.description: Denying slow deterioration because each step is small
failure_modes.example_scenario: Not recognizing market share erosion because each quarter's loss is 'small'

failure_modes.name: Sunk Cost Denial
failure_modes.description: Denying that past investments are lost to avoid pain of admitting failure
failure_modes.example_scenario: Continuing failed project because admitting failure is too painful

failure_modes.name: Mortality/Failure Denial
failure_modes.description: Denying that companies/investments can fail completely
failure_modes.example_scenario: Not considering bankruptcy scenario for leveraged company

failure_modes.name: Responsibility Denial
failure_modes.description: Denying own role in failures to avoid psychological pain
failure_modes.example_scenario: Blaming market conditions for poor investment when analysis was flawed

models.name: Excessive Self-Regard Tendency
models.description: We overestimate our own abilities, contributions, and the value of what we own.

failure_modes.name: Overconfidence in Own Analysis
failure_modes.description: Excessive confidence in own conclusions without adequate uncertainty
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyst certain of price target without acknowledging wide range of outcomes

failure_modes.name: Endowment Effect in Ideas
failure_modes.description: Overvaluing own ideas simply because they are yours
prevention_strategies: Value ideas by merit not origin
failure_modes.example_scenario: Defending flawed investment thesis because you developed it

failure_modes.name: Above-Average Effect
failure_modes.description: Believing own skills are above average when statistically unlikely
failure_modes.example_scenario: Believing you can beat the market when most professionals can't

failure_modes.name: Self-Serving Attribution
failure_modes.description: Attributing success to skill and failure to luck/circumstances
prevention_strategies: Analyze luck vs. skill in successes
failure_modes.example_scenario: Taking credit for bull market gains while blaming bear market losses on 'unprecedented events'

failure_modes.name: Blind Spot Blindness
failure_modes.description: Believing you are less biased than others
failure_modes.example_scenario: Believing your analysis is objective while others' are biased

failure_modes.description: Thinking you're better than you are
failure_modes.real_world_case: 90% of drivers think they're above average.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If you're never wrong, you're not tracking

failure_modes.description: Overvaluing what you own
failure_modes.real_world_case: Sellers wanting 2x what buyers will pay.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Ownership premium is typically 2-3x

failure_modes.description: Taking credit for success, blaming others for failure
failure_modes.real_world_case: CEOs crediting themselves in good times, blaming economy in bad.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Apply same standards to success and failure

failure_modes.description: Not knowing what you don't know
failure_modes.real_world_case: Dunning-Kruger effect - incompetent don't know they're incompetent.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Everyone has 3-5 major blind spots

failure_modes.description: Choosing comparisons that make you look good
failure_modes.real_world_case: Comparing to worst performers, not best.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Compare to top 10%, not bottom 50%

safeguards: Analyze luck vs. skill in successes

models.name: Overoptimism Tendency
models.description: We tend to be unrealistically optimistic about outcomes, especially our own.

failure_modes.name: Planning Fallacy
failure_modes.description: Underestimating time, cost, and risk while overestimating benefits
failure_modes.example_scenario: Project budget and timeline based on best-case scenario

failure_modes.name: Upside Overweighting
failure_modes.description: Focusing on potential gains while underweighting potential losses
prevention_strategies: Equal weight to upside and downside
failure_modes.example_scenario: Investment memo focuses on growth potential with one paragraph on risks

failure_modes.name: Success Rate Overestimation
failure_modes.description: Overestimating probability of success vs. base rates
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming 80% chance of successful product launch when base rate is 20%

failure_modes.name: Optimism Contagion
failure_modes.description: Group optimism reinforcing individual optimism
failure_modes.example_scenario: Investment committee all bullish, reinforcing each other's optimism

failure_modes.name: Survivorship Bias in Optimism
failure_modes.description: Optimism based on visible successes while failures are invisible
failure_modes.example_scenario: Optimistic about startup investing based on unicorn examples, ignoring 90% failure rate

safeguards: Equal weight to upside and downside

models.name: Deprival-Superreaction Tendency
models.description: We react more intensely to losses than to equivalent gains. Loss aversion drives much behavior.

failure_modes.name: Loss Aversion Overreaction
failure_modes.description: Disproportionate response to losses leading to poor decisions
failure_modes.example_scenario: Panic selling at market bottom to 'stop the pain'

failure_modes.name: Near-Miss Overvaluation
failure_modes.description: Overvaluing things almost obtained, leading to irrational pursuit
failure_modes.example_scenario: Overpaying for acquisition because you 'almost had it' in previous attempt

failure_modes.name: Status Quo Bias from Loss Framing
failure_modes.description: Preferring status quo because change is framed as loss
failure_modes.example_scenario: Not selling underperforming asset because selling 'locks in the loss'

failure_modes.name: Territorial Defense Overreaction
failure_modes.description: Excessive defense of existing position/market against threats
failure_modes.example_scenario: Destroying profitability to defend market share against new entrant

failure_modes.name: Reference Point Manipulation Blindness
failure_modes.description: Failing to recognize when reference points are being manipulated
failure_modes.example_scenario: Accepting bad deal because it's framed as 'better than' artificially bad alternative

failure_modes.description: Avoiding action to avoid potential loss
failure_modes.real_world_case: Not selling losing positions, hoping for recovery.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Losses feel 2x worse than equivalent gains

failure_modes.description: Continuing to avoid feeling loss
failure_modes.real_world_case: Concorde fallacy - continuing failed project.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Sunk costs are sunk - only future matters

failure_modes.description: Overreacting to almost losing
failure_modes.real_world_case: Panic selling after market dip.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Near-misses are normal, not signals

failure_modes.description: Defending territory beyond its value
failure_modes.real_world_case: Companies fighting for declining markets.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Defense should be proportional to value

failure_modes.description: Retaliation for feeling deprived
failure_modes.real_world_case: Lawsuits that cost more than the loss.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Revenge typically costs more than original loss

models.name: Social-Proof Tendency
models.description: We look to others to determine correct behavior, especially in uncertain situations.

failure_modes.name: Herd Following
failure_modes.description: Following crowd without independent analysis
failure_modes.example_scenario: Buying stock because 'everyone is buying it' without own analysis

failure_modes.name: Expert Consensus Overweighting
failure_modes.description: Overweighting expert consensus without examining underlying reasoning
failure_modes.example_scenario: Accepting analyst consensus price target without understanding assumptions

failure_modes.name: Uncertainty-Driven Social Proof
failure_modes.description: Relying more on social proof when uncertain, amplifying errors
failure_modes.example_scenario: In novel situation, following what others do without questioning if they know better

failure_modes.name: Similarity-Based Social Proof
failure_modes.description: Following people similar to you without evaluating their competence
failure_modes.example_scenario: Following investment strategy of peers without checking their actual returns

failure_modes.name: Cascade Amplification
failure_modes.description: Contributing to information cascade by adding to social proof
failure_modes.example_scenario: Adding bullish view because others are bullish, amplifying potential bubble

failure_modes.description: Following crowd without independent analysis
failure_modes.real_world_case: Dot-com bubble - everyone buying because everyone buying.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: When everyone agrees, be suspicious

failure_modes.description: Everyone thinks everyone else knows
failure_modes.real_world_case: No one asking questions in meetings.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If no one's questioning, no one's thinking

failure_modes.description: Following others when uncertain
failure_modes.real_world_case: Bystander effect - no one helps because no one helps.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: In uncertainty, social proof is least reliable

failure_modes.description: Following experts without verification
failure_modes.real_world_case: Following analyst recommendations blindly.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Experts are wrong 30-40% on complex issues

failure_modes.description: Being fooled by fake consensus
failure_modes.real_world_case: Fake reviews, astroturfing.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 10-30% of online reviews are fake

models.name: Contrast-Misreaction Tendency
models.description: We misjudge based on contrasts rather than absolute values, leading to poor decisions.

failure_modes.name: Anchoring to Wrong Comparison
failure_modes.description: Judging value by contrast to irrelevant anchor
failure_modes.example_scenario: Stock seems cheap at $50 because it was $100, ignoring that fair value is $30

failure_modes.name: Gradual Change Blindness
failure_modes.description: Missing significant changes because each step is small relative to previous
failure_modes.example_scenario: Not noticing margin erosion because each quarter's decline is small

failure_modes.name: Decoy Effect Manipulation
failure_modes.description: Being manipulated by strategically placed inferior option
failure_modes.example_scenario: Choosing expensive option because medium option is strategically priced as decoy

failure_modes.name: Contrast-Based Complacency
failure_modes.description: Accepting bad situation because it's better than worse alternative
prevention_strategies: Don't accept bad because not worst
failure_modes.example_scenario: Accepting poor returns because 'at least we didn't lose money'

failure_modes.name: Salesman's Contrast Trick
failure_modes.description: Being manipulated by showing expensive option first to make target seem reasonable
failure_modes.example_scenario: Buying expensive car because it's cheaper than first one shown

failure_modes.description: Judging by contrast, not absolute value
failure_modes.real_world_case: Expensive item seems cheap after seeing more expensive one.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Anchors can shift judgments by 50%+

failure_modes.description: Not noticing gradual changes
failure_modes.real_world_case: Slowly declining business not noticed until crisis.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 1% daily decline = 97% annual decline

failure_modes.description: Being manipulated by price contrasts
failure_modes.real_world_case: Decoy pricing making expensive option seem reasonable.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Decoys can shift choice by 30-50%

failure_modes.description: Spending more because others spend more
failure_modes.real_world_case: Keeping up with wealthy neighbors.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Reference group determines spending more than income

failure_modes.description: Judging performance by recent contrast
failure_modes.real_world_case: Good quarter after bad seems great, even if mediocre.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Judge against long-term average, not recent past

safeguards: Don't accept bad because not worst

models.name: Stress-Influence Tendency
models.description: Stress can cause both enhanced performance and dysfunction, including extreme reactions.

failure_modes.name: Stress-Induced Tunnel Vision
failure_modes.description: Stress narrows focus, missing important peripheral information
failure_modes.example_scenario: During crisis, focusing only on immediate problem while missing related issues

failure_modes.name: Stress-Induced Rigidity
failure_modes.description: Stress causes reversion to familiar patterns even when inappropriate
failure_modes.example_scenario: Applying old playbook to new crisis because stress prevents creative thinking

failure_modes.name: Stress Contagion
failure_modes.description: Stress spreading through team, amplifying poor decision-making
failure_modes.example_scenario: Panic spreading through trading floor leading to collective poor decisions

failure_modes.name: Stress-Performance Curve Misjudgment
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing when stress has crossed from enhancing to impairing performance
failure_modes.example_scenario: Continuing to work through extreme stress when performance has degraded

failure_modes.name: Post-Stress Overconfidence
failure_modes.description: Overconfidence after surviving stressful situation
prevention_strategies: Analyze luck vs. skill in survival
failure_modes.example_scenario: Taking more risk after surviving market crash, believing you can handle anything

failure_modes.description: Making worse decisions when stressed
failure_modes.real_world_case: Panic selling during market crashes.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Stress reduces decision quality by 30-50%

failure_modes.description: Focusing narrowly, missing big picture
failure_modes.real_world_case: Pilots fixating on one instrument in emergency.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Stress narrows attention by 50%+

failure_modes.description: Falling back on automatic behaviors
failure_modes.real_world_case: Trained responses overriding better judgment.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Under stress, habits dominate deliberation

failure_modes.description: Agreeing to things under pressure
failure_modes.real_world_case: Signing bad deals under time pressure.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Artificial urgency is manipulation signal

failure_modes.description: Not recognizing chronic stress effects
failure_modes.real_world_case: Burnout affecting all decisions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Chronic stress reduces cognitive function 20-40%

models.name: Availability-Misweighing Tendency
models.description: We overweight information that is easily available or vivid in memory.

failure_modes.name: Recency Bias
failure_modes.description: Overweighting recent events because they are more available in memory
failure_modes.example_scenario: Projecting recent growth rates forward without considering historical cycles

failure_modes.name: Vivid Example Overweighting
failure_modes.description: Overweighting dramatic or vivid examples vs. statistical base rates
failure_modes.example_scenario: Overestimating fraud risk because of memorable fraud case, ignoring low base rate

failure_modes.name: Media Availability Bias
failure_modes.description: Overweighting risks/opportunities that receive media coverage
failure_modes.example_scenario: Overweighting terrorism risk vs. car accidents because of media coverage

failure_modes.name: Personal Experience Overweighting
failure_modes.description: Overweighting own experience vs. broader data
failure_modes.example_scenario: Judging industry based on one company you worked at

failure_modes.name: Ease of Recall Bias
failure_modes.description: Judging frequency/probability by how easily examples come to mind
failure_modes.example_scenario: Overestimating probability of plane crash because crashes are memorable

failure_modes.description: Overweighting recent events
failure_modes.real_world_case: Overreacting to recent market moves.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Recent events are overweighted 3-5x

failure_modes.description: Overweighting vivid, memorable events
failure_modes.real_world_case: Fear of plane crashes vs car accidents.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Vivid events overweighted 10x+ vs statistics

failure_modes.description: Overweighting what media covers
failure_modes.real_world_case: Overestimating crime because of news coverage.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: News coverage ≠ actual frequency

failure_modes.description: Overweighting own experience vs data
failure_modes.real_world_case: Judging market by own portfolio performance.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Personal experience is tiny, biased sample

failure_modes.description: Overweighting easily recalled information
failure_modes.real_world_case: Overestimating risks that are easy to imagine.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Easy to recall ≠ likely to occur

models.name: Use-It-or-Lose-It Tendency

failure_modes.name: Knowledge Obsolescence
failure_modes.description: Relying on outdated knowledge without updating

failure_modes.name: Overreliance on Documented Knowledge
failure_modes.description: Relying on written procedures when tacit knowledge has been lost
failure_modes.example_scenario: Following investment checklist without understanding why each item matters

failure_modes.name: Institutional Memory Loss
failure_modes.description: Organization losing knowledge as experienced people leave
failure_modes.example_scenario: Repeating past mistakes because people who learned from them have left

failure_modes.name: Atrophied Critical Thinking
failure_modes.description: Critical thinking skills decay from disuse in conformist environment
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyst in yes-man culture loses ability to think critically

failure_modes.description: Losing skills through disuse
failure_modes.real_world_case: Doctors losing surgical skills without practice.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Skills decay 20-30% per year without practice

failure_modes.description: Knowledge becoming outdated
failure_modes.real_world_case: Technical skills becoming obsolete.

failure_modes.description: Relationships weakening without maintenance

failure_modes.description: Mental models becoming stale

failure_modes.description: Physical abilities declining without use

failure_modes.name: Sleep Deprivation Effects
failure_modes.description: Sleep deprivation impairing judgment similar to intoxication

failure_modes.name: Medication Side Effects
failure_modes.description: Prescription medications affecting cognitive function unrecognized

failure_modes.name: Withdrawal Effects
failure_modes.description: Withdrawal from substances affecting judgment

failure_modes.description: Making decisions while impaired
failure_modes.real_world_case: Alcohol-influenced business decisions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Any impairment affects judgment significantly

failure_modes.description: Dependence on substances for performance

failure_modes.description: Substances affecting emotional judgment

failure_modes.description: Withdrawal affecting decision-making

failure_modes.description: Overvaluing experience when environment has changed

failure_modes.name: Nostalgia Bias
failure_modes.description: Romanticizing past and applying outdated approaches
failure_modes.example_scenario: Preferring old investment style because 'it worked in the good old days'

failure_modes.name: Succession Planning Failure

failure_modes.name: Generational Blind Spots

failure_modes.description: Not recognizing own cognitive decline
failure_modes.real_world_case: Aging executives not recognizing slowing.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Cognitive decline starts around 45-50

failure_modes.description: Overvaluing experience vs current knowledge
failure_modes.real_world_case: Experienced managers dismissing new approaches.

failure_modes.description: Becoming too risk-averse with age

failure_modes.name: Authority Symbols Over Substance

failure_modes.name: Hierarchical Information Filtering

failure_modes.name: Authority-Induced Groupthink

failure_modes.description: Following authority without question

failure_modes.description: Assuming expertise in one area transfers

failure_modes.description: Responding to symbols of authority

models.name: Twaddle Tendency

failure_modes.name: Complexity Theater

failure_modes.name: Meeting Proliferation

failure_modes.name: Bikeshedding

failure_modes.name: Activity vs. Progress Confusion
failure_modes.description: Confusing being busy with making progress

failure_modes.description: Thinking complex = smart

failure_modes.description: Talking without saying anything

failure_modes.description: Accepting nonsense from credentialed sources

failure_modes.description: Fooling yourself with your own nonsense

models.name: Reason-Respecting Tendency

failure_modes.name: Reason Inflation

failure_modes.name: Single Reason Sufficiency

failure_modes.name: Circular Reasoning Acceptance

failure_modes.description: Being satisfied with any explanation

failure_modes.description: Being manipulated through reasons

failure_modes.description: Accepting reasons without checking

failure_modes.name: Cascade Trigger Failure

failure_modes.name: Historical Lollapalooza Amnesia

failure_modes.name: Source Selection Bias

models.name: Hindsight Bias

failure_modes.name: Anchoring on Initial View
