failure_modes.example_scenario: Concluding based on first information without full analysis

failure_modes.name: First Conclusion Lock-In
failure_modes.description: Locking into first conclusion despite contrary evidence
failure_modes.example_scenario: Maintaining first conclusion despite contradicting evidence

failure_modes.name: Confirmation After Conclusion
failure_modes.description: Seeking only confirming evidence after conclusion
failure_modes.example_scenario: Only looking for evidence supporting first conclusion

failure_modes.name: Conclusion Anchoring
failure_modes.description: First conclusion anchoring subsequent analysis
failure_modes.example_scenario: All subsequent analysis biased by first conclusion

failure_modes.name: Conclusion Communication Premature
failure_modes.description: Communicating conclusion before fully validated
failure_modes.example_scenario: Sharing conclusion that later needs to be revised

models.name: Anchoring Bias
models.description: Initial information disproportionately influences subsequent judgments.

failure_modes.name: Irrelevant Anchor Influence
failure_modes.description: Being influenced by anchors that have no logical relevance
failure_modes.example_scenario: Valuation anchored to IPO price which has no bearing on current value

failure_modes.name: Insufficient Adjustment
failure_modes.description: Adjusting insufficiently from anchor even when adjustment is needed
failure_modes.example_scenario: Adjusting analyst price target by 10% when fundamentals suggest 50% change needed

failure_modes.name: Self-Generated Anchor
failure_modes.description: Being anchored by your own previous estimates
failure_modes.example_scenario: Sticking close to your original price target despite changed circumstances

failure_modes.name: Negotiation Anchor Trap
failure_modes.description: Being anchored by counterparty's opening position
failure_modes.example_scenario: Negotiating around seller's asking price rather than your own valuation

failure_modes.name: Historical Price Anchoring
failure_modes.description: Anchoring on historical prices that may no longer be relevant
failure_modes.example_scenario: Thinking stock is cheap because it's down 50% from highs

models.name: Incentive-Caused Bias
models.description: Professional incentives unconsciously bias judgment and recommendations.

failure_modes.name: Self-Interest Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing how own incentives bias analysis
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyst bullish on stock their firm is underwriting

failure_modes.name: Professional Incentive Distortion
failure_modes.description: Professional incentives unconsciously shaping recommendations
failure_modes.example_scenario: Broker recommending active trading because it generates commissions

failure_modes.name: Institutional Incentive Capture
failure_modes.description: Institutional incentives overriding individual judgment
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyst maintaining buy rating because firm has banking relationship

failure_modes.name: Incentive Rationalization
failure_modes.description: Constructing rational-sounding justifications for incentive-driven conclusions
failure_modes.example_scenario: Building sophisticated model that happens to justify the deal you want to do

failure_modes.name: Incentive Contagion
failure_modes.description: Adopting others' biased views because of their incentives
failure_modes.example_scenario: Trusting sell-side research without considering their incentives

models.name: Pavlovian Association/Conditioning
models.description: We form automatic associations through repeated pairing of stimuli.

failure_modes.name: Conditioned Response Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing conditioned responses driving behavior
failure_modes.example_scenario: Automatically buying dips because it worked before, without analyzing current situation

failure_modes.name: False Association
failure_modes.description: Creating associations between unrelated events
failure_modes.example_scenario: Believing certain market indicators predict outcomes when correlation is spurious

failure_modes.name: Extinction Failure
failure_modes.description: Continuing conditioned response after conditions have changed
prevention_strategies: Regularly review if conditions still apply
failure_modes.example_scenario: Continuing to buy dips in bear market because it worked in bull market

failure_modes.name: Generalization Error
failure_modes.description: Generalizing conditioned response to dissimilar situations
failure_modes.example_scenario: Applying strategy that worked in one market to completely different market

failure_modes.name: Emotional Conditioning
failure_modes.description: Emotional responses conditioned by past experiences distorting judgment
failure_modes.example_scenario: Fear of a sector because of past losses there, even when fundamentals are different

safeguards: Regularly review if conditions still apply

models.name: Hyperbolic Discounting/Short-Termism
models.description: We overvalue immediate rewards relative to future ones.

failure_modes.name: Present Bias
failure_modes.description: Overweighting immediate outcomes vs. future outcomes
failure_modes.example_scenario: Selling winning position for immediate gain rather than holding for larger future gain

failure_modes.name: Quarterly Earnings Myopia
failure_modes.description: Overweighting quarterly results vs. long-term value creation
failure_modes.example_scenario: Selling stock after one bad quarter despite strong long-term thesis

failure_modes.name: Impatience with Compounding
failure_modes.description: Undervaluing slow compounding in favor of quick gains
failure_modes.example_scenario: Abandoning 15% compounder for speculative 100% gain attempt

failure_modes.name: Career Risk Short-Termism
failure_modes.description: Short-term focus driven by career risk of underperformance
failure_modes.example_scenario: Avoiding undervalued stock because it might underperform in near term

failure_modes.name: Inconsistent Time Preferences
failure_modes.description: Applying different discount rates to similar future periods
prevention_strategies: Apply same standards to all periods
failure_modes.example_scenario: Heavily discounting year 2 vs year 1, but not year 3 vs year 2

safeguards: Apply same standards to all periods

models.name: Representativeness Bias
models.description: We judge probability by similarity to stereotypes rather than base rates.

failure_modes.name: Base Rate Neglect
failure_modes.description: Ignoring base rates in favor of representativeness
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming startup will succeed because founders fit successful founder stereotype, ignoring 90% failure rate

failure_modes.name: Sample Size Insensitivity
failure_modes.description: Drawing strong conclusions from small samples that seem representative
failure_modes.example_scenario: Concluding strategy works based on 3 successful trades

failure_modes.name: Conjunction Fallacy
failure_modes.description: Judging specific scenarios as more likely than general ones
failure_modes.example_scenario: Believing detailed bull case more likely than simple 'stock goes up'

failure_modes.name: Stereotype Matching
failure_modes.description: Judging probability by fit to stereotype rather than evidence
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming company will fail because CEO doesn't fit successful CEO stereotype

failure_modes.name: Regression Ignorance
failure_modes.description: Not expecting regression to mean after extreme observations
failure_modes.example_scenario: Expecting exceptional year to continue rather than regress to average

models.name: Status Quo Bias/Habit Persistence
models.description: We prefer the current state of affairs and resist change.

failure_modes.name: Default Option Preference
failure_modes.description: Preferring current state simply because it's the default
prevention_strategies: Consider opportunity cost of status quo
failure_modes.example_scenario: Keeping underperforming investment because selling requires action

failure_modes.name: Change Aversion
failure_modes.description: Resisting change even when change is beneficial
failure_modes.example_scenario: Not updating investment process despite evidence of better approaches

failure_modes.name: Endowment Effect
failure_modes.description: Overvaluing what you already own
prevention_strategies: Value holdings as if you didn't own them
Would you buy at current price?
failure_modes.example_scenario: Refusing to sell stock at price you wouldn't pay to buy it

failure_modes.name: Process Ossification
failure_modes.description: Continuing processes because 'that's how we've always done it'
failure_modes.example_scenario: Using outdated valuation methods because they're familiar

failure_modes.name: Omission Bias
failure_modes.description: Preferring inaction over action even when action is better
failure_modes.example_scenario: Not selling deteriorating position because selling feels like 'doing something wrong'

safeguards: Value holdings as if you didn't own them
Consider opportunity cost of status quo
Would you buy at current price?

models.name: Inversion
models.description: Invert, always invert. Solve problems backwards. Think about what you want to avoid.

failure_modes.name: Inversion Omission
failure_modes.description: Failing to apply inversion when it would reveal important insights
failure_modes.example_scenario: Investment thesis only considers how it could succeed, not how it could fail

failure_modes.name: Superficial Inversion
failure_modes.description: Applying inversion superficially without deep analysis
failure_modes.example_scenario: Risk section lists obvious risks without analyzing probability or impact

failure_modes.name: Inversion Without Action
failure_modes.description: Identifying risks through inversion but not acting on them
failure_modes.example_scenario: Identifying key risk but proceeding without mitigation plan

failure_modes.name: Asymmetric Inversion
failure_modes.description: Applying inversion to some scenarios but not others
failure_modes.example_scenario: Inverting competitive risks but not management risks

failure_modes.name: Inversion Paralysis
failure_modes.description: Excessive focus on what could go wrong preventing action
failure_modes.example_scenario: Never investing because you can always find something that could go wrong

failure_modes.description: Only inverting part of the problem
failure_modes.real_world_case: Kodak inverted 'how to sell more film' but not 'how to avoid obsolescence'.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Invert at least 3 levels: tactical, strategic, existential

failure_modes.description: Seeing so many ways to fail that action stops
failure_modes.real_world_case: Analysis paralysis in startups - seeing all failure modes prevents launching.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Inversion should take 10-20% of planning time, not 80%

failure_modes.description: Inversion creates excessive negativity
failure_modes.real_world_case: VCs who only see failure modes miss breakthrough opportunities.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Inversion should inform, not dominate, decisions

failure_modes.description: Inverting to wrong opposite
failure_modes.real_world_case: Inverting 'how to succeed' to 'how to not fail' misses that not failing isn't succeeding.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Most problems have 3+ valid inversions, not just one

failure_modes.description: Identifying failure modes but not preventing them
failure_modes.real_world_case: Risk registers that identify risks but don't drive mitigation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Each identified risk needs owner and mitigation within 30 days

failure_modes.description: Inverting something that doesn't matter
failure_modes.real_world_case: Avoiding wrong failures while missing real risks.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Invert the 20% that matters most

failure_modes.description: Thinking you've found all failure modes
failure_modes.real_world_case: Black swan events not in inversion list.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Your inversion list is always incomplete

models.name: Checklist Approach
models.description: Use systematic checklists to avoid omission errors and ensure comprehensive analysis.

failure_modes.name: Checklist as Checkbox
failure_modes.description: Going through checklist mechanically without genuine analysis
failure_modes.example_scenario: Checking 'competitive advantage: yes' without analyzing what it actually is

failure_modes.name: Incomplete Checklist
failure_modes.description: Checklist missing important items for the situation
failure_modes.example_scenario: Using generic checklist that misses industry-specific risks

failure_modes.name: Checklist Overconfidence
failure_modes.description: False confidence from completing checklist
failure_modes.example_scenario: Feeling confident because checklist is complete, missing non-checklist risks

failure_modes.name: Outdated Checklist
failure_modes.description: Using checklist that hasn't been updated for changed conditions
failure_modes.example_scenario: Using pre-2008 checklist that doesn't include liquidity risk items

failure_modes.name: Checklist Rigidity
failure_modes.description: Following checklist rigidly when situation requires flexibility
failure_modes.example_scenario: Rejecting opportunity because it doesn't fit standard checklist despite unique merits

models.name: Two-Track Analysis
models.description: Analyze problems through both rational factors and psychological/subconscious influences.

failure_modes.name: Single Track Dominance
failure_modes.description: One track (rational or psychological) dominates analysis
failure_modes.example_scenario: Pure financial analysis ignoring psychological factors affecting management

failure_modes.name: Track Integration Failure
failure_modes.description: Analyzing both tracks but failing to integrate insights
failure_modes.example_scenario: Rational analysis says buy, psychological says sell, no resolution

failure_modes.name: Psychological Track Superficiality
failure_modes.description: Superficial treatment of psychological factors
failure_modes.example_scenario: Mentioning 'management may be overconfident' without analyzing evidence

failure_modes.name: Self-Analysis Blind Spot
failure_modes.description: Applying two-track to others but not to own analysis
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyzing target company's biases while ignoring own confirmation bias

failure_modes.name: Rational Track Overconfidence
failure_modes.description: Overconfidence in rational analysis, underweighting psychological
failure_modes.example_scenario: Trusting financial model despite management incentive misalignment

models.name: Elementary Worldly Wisdom
models.description: Build a latticework of basic models from multiple disciplines for better thinking.

failure_modes.name: Narrow Mental Model Set
failure_modes.description: Using too few mental models, missing important perspectives
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyzing business only through financial lens, missing psychological and competitive dynamics

failure_modes.name: Model Misapplication
failure_modes.description: Applying mental model to situation where it doesn't fit
failure_modes.example_scenario: Applying supply/demand model to situation driven by network effects

failure_modes.name: Model Overconfidence
failure_modes.description: Excessive confidence in mental model predictions
failure_modes.example_scenario: Treating moat analysis as definitive when moats can erode unexpectedly

failure_modes.name: Model Updating Failure
failure_modes.description: Not updating mental models based on new evidence or failures
failure_modes.example_scenario: Using pre-internet mental models for digital businesses

failure_modes.name: Model Conflict Paralysis
failure_modes.description: Paralysis when different mental models give conflicting answers
failure_modes.example_scenario: Valuation model says buy, competitive analysis says sell, no decision made

models.name: Latticework of Mental Models
models.description: Facts must hang together on a latticework of theory to be useful.

failure_modes.name: Isolated Model Application
failure_modes.description: Applying models in isolation rather than as interconnected latticework
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyzing moat, management, and valuation separately without integration

failure_modes.name: Latticework Gaps
failure_modes.description: Missing important models in the latticework
failure_modes.example_scenario: Latticework missing psychology models, leading to behavioral blind spots

failure_modes.name: Latticework Rigidity
failure_modes.description: Rigid latticework that doesn't adapt to new situations
failure_modes.example_scenario: Applying same latticework to tech startup as to mature industrial company

failure_modes.name: Latticework Complexity Overload
failure_modes.description: Latticework too complex to apply effectively
failure_modes.example_scenario: Trying to apply 50 models to every situation, losing focus

failure_modes.name: Latticework Without Practice
failure_modes.description: Having latticework knowledge without practiced application
failure_modes.example_scenario: Knowing about mental models but not actually using them in analysis

models.name: Multidisciplinary Approach
models.description: Draw models from multiple disciplines - all wisdom is not in one academic department.

failure_modes.name: Disciplinary Silos
failure_modes.description: Staying within one discipline when multiple are needed
failure_modes.example_scenario: Financial analyst missing psychological factors that drive the business

failure_modes.name: Superficial Multidisciplinarity
failure_modes.description: Surface-level application of other disciplines without deep understanding
failure_modes.example_scenario: Misapplying evolutionary concepts to business without understanding biology

failure_modes.name: Discipline Translation Failure
failure_modes.description: Failing to translate insights between disciplines
failure_modes.example_scenario: Understanding physics concept but not applying it to business situation

failure_modes.name: Discipline Hierarchy Bias
failure_modes.description: Valuing some disciplines over others inappropriately
failure_modes.example_scenario: Dismissing psychology insights because 'it's not as rigorous as finance'

failure_modes.name: Jack of All Trades Trap
failure_modes.description: Broad but shallow knowledge across disciplines
failure_modes.example_scenario: Knowing a little about everything but not enough to apply any discipline well

models.name: Circle of Competence
models.description: Know the boundaries of your knowledge and stay within them.

failure_modes.name: Circle Overestimation
failure_modes.description: Believing circle of competence is larger than it actually is
failure_modes.example_scenario: Tech investor believing they understand biotech because 'it's all science'

failure_modes.name: Circle Boundary Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not knowing where circle of competence ends
failure_modes.example_scenario: Gradually drifting into unfamiliar sectors without recognizing it

failure_modes.name: Circle Stagnation
failure_modes.description: Not expanding circle of competence over time
failure_modes.example_scenario: Retail investor not learning about e-commerce as it transforms retail

failure_modes.name: Circle Shrinkage Denial
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing when competence has eroded
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming expertise in industry you haven't followed for years

failure_modes.name: Circle Rigidity
failure_modes.description: Refusing to venture outside circle even when appropriate
failure_modes.example_scenario: Missing great opportunity because it's slightly outside current circle

failure_modes.description: Thinking you know more than you do
failure_modes.real_world_case: Doctors investing in restaurants - medical expertise doesn't transfer.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 10,000 hours in domain to claim competence

failure_modes.description: Not expanding competence over time
failure_modes.real_world_case: Investors who never learn new industries miss opportunities.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Expand circle 10% annually through deliberate learning

failure_modes.description: Competence eroding without maintenance
failure_modes.real_world_case: Technology skills becoming obsolete without continuous learning.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Technical competence half-life is 5-7 years

failure_modes.description: Luck mistaken for skill expands perceived circle
failure_modes.real_world_case: Bull market investors thinking they're skilled.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Need 10+ year track record across cycles to verify competence

failure_modes.description: Knowing area but not better than competition
failure_modes.real_world_case: Retail investors 'knowing' stocks but competing against professionals.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Need top-decile knowledge to have edge in competitive areas

failure_modes.description: Thinking you know more than you do
failure_modes.real_world_case: Experts in one field opining on others.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Your circle is smaller than you think

failure_modes.description: Staying too narrow
failure_modes.real_world_case: Never learning new domains.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Expand circle 10% per year

failure_modes.description: Wrong understanding of what you know
failure_modes.real_world_case: Thinking you understand when you don't.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Test your knowledge against reality

failure_modes.description: Using it to avoid learning
failure_modes.real_world_case: Not learning because 'not my circle'.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Circle should grow, not be excuse

models.name: First Principles Thinking
models.description: Break down problems to fundamental truths and reason up from there.

failure_modes.name: False First Principles
failure_modes.description: Treating assumptions as first principles when they're not fundamental
failure_modes.example_scenario: Treating 'customers want low prices' as first principle when they actually want value

failure_modes.name: Incomplete Decomposition
failure_modes.description: Not breaking problem down to truly fundamental components
failure_modes.example_scenario: Stopping decomposition at 'we need to grow revenue' without breaking down further

failure_modes.name: Reconstruction Failure
failure_modes.description: Decomposing to first principles but failing to reconstruct solution
failure_modes.example_scenario: Understanding fundamental physics but not designing the product

failure_modes.name: First Principles Overuse
failure_modes.description: Using first principles when analogy or convention would be more efficient
failure_modes.example_scenario: Deriving accounting from first principles when GAAP works fine

failure_modes.name: Context-Free First Principles
failure_modes.description: Applying first principles without considering context
failure_modes.example_scenario: First principles say X is optimal but regulatory constraints make it impossible

failure_modes.description: Assumptions masquerading as first principles
failure_modes.real_world_case: Theranos - 'blood tests need small samples' wasn't actually a first principle, it was a constraint.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: True first principles are provable from physics or mathematics

failure_modes.description: Reasoning from scratch without understanding why conventions exist
failure_modes.real_world_case: Tech disruption of healthcare - ignored regulatory reasons for existing practices.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Spend 100+ hours learning domain before first-principles redesign

failure_modes.mode: First principles as excuse for reinventing wheel
failure_modes.description: Rebuilding what already works well
failure_modes.real_world_case: Companies rebuilding standard software instead of using proven solutions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Reinvention should provide 10x improvement to justify cost

failure_modes.description: Breaking everything down prevents action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Philosophers who can't make decisions because everything needs examination.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: First principles analysis should take hours to days, not weeks

failure_modes.description: Reductionism misses emergent properties
failure_modes.real_world_case: Understanding neurons doesn't explain consciousness - emergence matters.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Complex systems have emergent properties not predictable from components

failure_modes.description: Ignoring valid existing solutions
failure_modes.real_world_case: Rebuilding what already works well.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Only first-principles when existing solutions fail

failure_modes.description: Going too deep, never concluding
failure_modes.real_world_case: Endless questioning without action.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Stop when you have actionable insight

failure_modes.description: Breaking down loses system effects
failure_modes.real_world_case: Analyzing parts but missing how they interact.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Whole is often more than sum of parts

failure_modes.description: Dismissing expertise because you 'figured it out'
failure_modes.real_world_case: Newcomers dismissing industry knowledge.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: First principles + expertise > either alone

models.name: Second-Order Thinking
models.description: Think beyond first effects to subsequent consequences.

failure_modes.description: Not thinking far enough ahead
failure_modes.real_world_case: Rent control - second order is lower supply, third order is housing crisis, fourth order is homelessness.
safeguards: Think to third and fourth order
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Important decisions need analysis to at least 4th order effects

failure_modes.description: Considering effects without likelihood weighting
failure_modes.real_world_case: Worrying about asteroid impact while ignoring car accidents.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Weight effects by probability × magnitude

failure_modes.description: Too many second-order effects to process
failure_modes.real_world_case: Policy makers unable to act because every action has countless effects.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Focus on effects > 10% probability and > 10% impact

failure_modes.description: Claiming to know second-order effects that are unknowable
failure_modes.real_world_case: Economic forecasts - second-order effects are largely unpredictable.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Second-order predictions beyond 1 year have < 50% accuracy

failure_modes.description: Linear thinking when effects loop back
failure_modes.real_world_case: Social media algorithms - second-order effects feed back to change first-order behavior.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Most social/economic systems have feedback loops within 3 orders

failure_modes.description: Not thinking beyond immediate effects
failure_modes.real_world_case: Rent control reducing housing supply.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Always ask 'and then what?' at least twice

failure_modes.description: Going too many orders deep
failure_modes.real_world_case: Paralysis from considering all possible effects.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 2-3 orders usually sufficient

failure_modes.description: Predicting wrong downstream effects
failure_modes.real_world_case: Predicting effects that don't materialize.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Second-order predictions are less accurate

failure_modes.description: Using complexity to avoid action
failure_modes.real_world_case: Not acting because 'it's complicated'.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Imperfect action > perfect analysis

models.name: Occam's Razor
models.description: Prefer simpler explanations over complex ones when equally valid.

failure_modes.description: Making things too simple, missing important complexity
failure_modes.real_world_case: Simple models missing critical variables.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simple as possible, but no simpler

failure_modes.description: Preferring complex explanations when simple ones work
failure_modes.real_world_case: Elaborate trading strategies underperforming simple index.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simple strategies beat complex 70% of time

failure_modes.description: Simplifying wrong aspect of problem
failure_modes.real_world_case: Simplifying user interface but complicating user journey.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simplify what matters to user, not what's easy to simplify

failure_modes.mode: Simplicity as excuse for not understanding
failure_modes.description: Using Occam's Razor to avoid deep analysis
failure_modes.real_world_case: Simple explanation that's simply wrong.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simplicity should emerge from understanding, not replace it

failure_modes.description: Simple in one context, complex in another
failure_modes.real_world_case: Solution simple for experts, complex for novices.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simplicity is relative to the audience

failure_modes.description: Applying Occam's Razor where complexity is real
failure_modes.real_world_case: Climate models - simple models miss critical interactions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Complex systems may require complex models - simplicity isn't always better

failure_modes.description: Preferring familiar explanations over simpler ones
failure_modes.real_world_case: Geocentric model was familiar but more complex than heliocentric.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Count assumptions and entities, not familiarity

failure_modes.description: Simplifying before understanding
failure_modes.real_world_case: Early disease theories - miasma theory was simple but wrong.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Need data explaining > 90% of observations before simplifying

failure_modes.mode: Occam's Razor as excuse for ignorance
failure_modes.description: Using simplicity to avoid learning complexity
failure_modes.real_world_case: Dismissing quantum mechanics as 'too complex' when it's necessary.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simplicity preference shouldn't override explanatory power

failure_modes.description: Preferring simple even when complex is right
failure_modes.real_world_case: Simple model failing in complex reality.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Reality is often complex

failure_modes.description: Simplifying wrong dimension
failure_modes.real_world_case: Fewer variables but wrong variables.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simplicity in right dimensions

failure_modes.description: Using simplicity to avoid deep analysis
failure_modes.real_world_case: Simple answer because complex is hard.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Simplicity should emerge from understanding

models.name: Hanlon's Razor
models.description: Don't attribute to malice what can be explained by stupidity or incompetence.

failure_modes.description: Attributing to stupidity what is actually malicious
failure_modes.real_world_case: Enron - what looked like incompetence was deliberate fraud.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 3+ 'mistakes' benefiting same party suggests malice

failure_modes.description: Giving benefit of doubt to those who don't deserve it
failure_modes.real_world_case: Repeated fraud by same actors excused as mistakes.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Same 'mistake' twice is pattern, not accident

failure_modes.description: Missing institutional bad behavior
failure_modes.real_world_case: Tobacco industry - decades of deliberate deception, not incompetence.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Industry-wide 'mistakes' suggest systemic issues

failure_modes.description: Culture makes malice invisible
failure_modes.real_world_case: Financial industry pre-2008 - predatory lending normalized.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If victims consistently harmed, malice or negligence distinction matters less

failure_modes.description: Being taken advantage of through excessive charity
failure_modes.real_world_case: Ponzi scheme victims who kept believing despite red flags.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Trust but verify - Hanlon's doesn't mean ignore evidence

failure_modes.description: Assuming stupidity when malice is real
failure_modes.real_world_case: Being exploited by assuming good faith.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Three 'mistakes' in same direction = intent

failure_modes.description: Giving benefit of doubt to bad actors
failure_modes.real_world_case: Fraud excused as incompetence.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If they benefit from 'mistakes', suspect intent

failure_modes.description: Not recognizing strategic incompetence
failure_modes.real_world_case: Playing dumb to avoid responsibility.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Incompetence in one area, competence in others = suspicious

failure_modes.description: Using it to avoid conflict
failure_modes.real_world_case: Not confronting bad behavior.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Intent doesn't matter if behavior continues

failure_modes.description: Attributing system failures to individual incompetence
failure_modes.real_world_case: Blaming individuals for system design failures.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If multiple people fail, it's the system

models.name: Falsification/Disconfirming Evidence
models.description: Actively seek evidence that disproves your hypothesis, like Darwin did.

models.name: Scenario Analysis
models.description: Consider multiple possible futures and plan for various outcomes.

models.name: Mental Accounting
models.description: Understand how people psychologically frame and categorize money differently.

models.name: Black Swan Events
models.description: Prepare for extreme, hard-to-predict events with massive impact.

models.name: Gray Rhino Events
models.description: Recognize obvious but neglected big risks that people ignore.

models.name: Vivification
models.description: Make ideas vivid and concrete so they stick in memory.

models.name: Man-with-a-Hammer Tendency
models.description: Avoid overusing one model - to a man with a hammer, everything looks like a nail.

models.name: Supply and Demand
models.description: Prices are determined by the interaction of supply and demand.

failure_modes.name: Static Supply/Demand Analysis
failure_modes.description: Treating supply and demand as static when they're dynamic
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming current supply shortage will persist without modeling supply response

failure_modes.name: Elasticity Misjudgment
failure_modes.description: Misjudging price elasticity of supply or demand
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming demand will stay constant if prices rise when demand is actually elastic

failure_modes.name: Supply Response Timing
failure_modes.description: Misjudging how quickly supply can respond to price signals
failure_modes.example_scenario: Expecting commodity supply to increase immediately when it takes years to bring new capacity online

failure_modes.name: Demand Substitution Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not considering demand substitution effects
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyzing oil demand without considering electric vehicle substitution

failure_modes.name: Non-Price Factors Neglect
failure_modes.description: Focusing only on price while ignoring other supply/demand factors
failure_modes.example_scenario: Modeling demand based only on price when quality and brand matter more

failure_modes.description: Assuming all goods respond equally to price changes
failure_modes.real_world_case: Netflix 2011 price hike - raised prices 60%, lost 800,000 subscribers. Underestimated demand elasticity for streaming vs DVD.
safeguards: Run price elasticity analysis before changes
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Price elasticity > 1.5 indicates high sensitivity

failure_modes.description: Using point-in-time supply/demand without considering shifts
failure_modes.real_world_case: Oil price collapse 2014-2016 - analysts focused on current supply, missed shale production ramp-up shifting supply curve permanently.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Update models quarterly minimum

failure_modes.description: Traditional supply/demand assumes independent buyers
failure_modes.real_world_case: Blackberry collapse - demand wasn't just about price/features, but network effects of app ecosystem. Traditional analysis missed this.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Network effect multiplier > 1.2x indicates significant impact

failure_modes.mode: Confusing correlation with causation in price movements
failure_modes.description: Assuming price changes caused demand changes when third factors involved
failure_modes.real_world_case: Housing bubble 2008 - rising prices seemed to increase demand (wealth effect), but both were caused by loose credit.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: R-squared > 0.7 without controls is suspicious

failure_modes.description: Assuming supply can scale smoothly with demand
failure_modes.real_world_case: Semiconductor shortage 2021 - auto industry assumed chips would scale with demand, missed 2-year fab construction time.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Lead time > 6 months indicates constraint risk

failure_modes.description: Not understanding how price affects demand
failure_modes.real_world_case: Raising prices on elastic goods.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Know your price elasticity

failure_modes.description: Not anticipating supply disruptions
failure_modes.real_world_case: COVID supply chain disruptions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Plan for supply shocks

failure_modes.description: Misjudging future demand
failure_modes.real_world_case: Over-building capacity.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Forecasts are always wrong - plan for variance

failure_modes.description: Not seeing competitive alternatives
failure_modes.real_world_case: Pricing without considering alternatives.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Substitutes cap your pricing power

failure_modes.description: Assuming market reaches equilibrium
failure_modes.real_world_case: Persistent shortages or surpluses.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Markets don't always clear

models.name: Elasticity
models.description: Sensitivity of quantity demanded or supplied to changes in price or other factors.

models.name: Opportunity Cost
models.description: The true cost of anything is what you give up to get it.

failure_modes.name: Opportunity Cost Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not considering what else could be done with the same resources
failure_modes.example_scenario: Evaluating investment without considering what else the capital could do

failure_modes.name: Sunk Cost Confusion
failure_modes.description: Confusing sunk costs with opportunity costs
prevention_strategies: Focus on future costs and benefits
failure_modes.example_scenario: Continuing project because of money already spent rather than future opportunity cost

failure_modes.name: Time Opportunity Cost Neglect
failure_modes.description: Not considering the opportunity cost of time
failure_modes.example_scenario: Spending 100 hours on analysis that could have been spent on higher-value activities

failure_modes.name: Attention Opportunity Cost
failure_modes.description: Not considering the opportunity cost of attention and focus
failure_modes.example_scenario: Tracking 50 positions when attention would be better spent on 10

failure_modes.name: Dynamic Opportunity Cost
failure_modes.description: Not updating opportunity cost as circumstances change
failure_modes.example_scenario: Holding investment based on old opportunity cost when better alternatives now exist

failure_modes.description: Only comparing obvious alternatives, missing creative options
failure_modes.real_world_case: Kodak's digital camera decision - compared digital vs film, missed opportunity to become imaging software company.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Consider minimum 5 alternatives for major decisions

failure_modes.description: Not accounting for when opportunities expire
failure_modes.real_world_case: Yahoo's Google acquisition pass (2002) - $5B seemed expensive, didn't account for rapidly closing window.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Opportunity half-life < 2 years requires urgent evaluation

failure_modes.description: Past investments distorting opportunity cost calculations
failure_modes.real_world_case: Concorde project - UK/France continued despite clear opportunity cost of capital, because of sunk costs.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: If continuing NPV < 0, stop regardless of sunk costs

failure_modes.description: Not valuing flexibility and future choices
failure_modes.real_world_case: Amazon's AWS investment - seemed like opportunity cost vs retail, but created massive optionality.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Option value can exceed 50% of NPV in uncertain environments

failure_modes.description: Not applying opportunity cost to own time and energy
failure_modes.real_world_case: Founders doing $15/hour tasks - many startup founders do bookkeeping instead of fundraising or product work.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Tasks below 25% of hourly value should be delegated

failure_modes.description: Not considering alternatives foregone
failure_modes.real_world_case: Holding cash without considering returns.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Every choice has opportunity cost

failure_modes.description: Comparing to wrong alternative
failure_modes.real_world_case: Comparing to risk-free rate when equity is alternative.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Compare to realistic best alternative

failure_modes.description: Not seeing non-obvious alternatives
failure_modes.real_world_case: Time spent on project vs other uses.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Time and attention have opportunity cost

failure_modes.description: Unable to decide due to opportunity costs
failure_modes.real_world_case: Analysis paralysis from too many options.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Deciding has value - don't over-analyze

failure_modes.description: Confusing sunk costs with opportunity costs
failure_modes.real_world_case: Continuing bad investment because of past spending.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Sunk costs are irrelevant to future decisions

models.name: Comparative Advantage
models.description: Specialize in what you do relatively better, even if not absolutely better.

failure_modes.name: Absolute vs Comparative Confusion
failure_modes.description: Confusing absolute advantage with comparative advantage
failure_modes.example_scenario: Insourcing activity because you're good at it, ignoring you're even better at something else

failure_modes.name: Static Comparative Advantage
failure_modes.description: Treating comparative advantage as static when it evolves
failure_modes.example_scenario: Relying on current comparative advantage without building future capabilities

failure_modes.name: Comparative Advantage Erosion
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing erosion of comparative advantage
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming cost advantage will persist while competitors are catching up

failure_modes.name: Narrow Comparative Advantage View
failure_modes.description: Defining comparative advantage too narrowly
failure_modes.example_scenario: Focusing on manufacturing advantage while missing distribution advantage

failure_modes.name: Comparative Advantage Overconfidence
failure_modes.description: Overconfidence in sustainability of comparative advantage
failure_modes.example_scenario: Believing brand advantage is permanent when customer preferences are shifting

failure_modes.description: Assuming advantages are permanent rather than dynamic
failure_modes.real_world_case: US manufacturing decline - assumed service economy advantage was permanent, missed China's rapid capability building.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Advantage eroding > 5% annually requires action

failure_modes.description: Theoretical advantage doesn't account for real-world frictions
failure_modes.real_world_case: Offshoring failures - many companies found coordination costs, quality issues, and IP risks exceeded labor savings.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Transaction costs > 20% of savings negates advantage

failure_modes.description: Focusing on being best rather than relative efficiency
failure_modes.real_world_case: Japan's rice farming - maintains rice production despite being worse at it than manufacturing, due to political rather than economic logic.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Opportunity cost ratio > 2:1 indicates misallocation

failure_modes.description: Optimizing for efficiency without considering security
failure_modes.real_world_case: European energy dependence on Russia - comparative advantage said buy cheap Russian gas, ignored strategic vulnerability.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Single supplier > 40% of critical input is dangerous

failure_modes.mode: Ignoring learning curves and scale effects
failure_modes.description: Current comparative advantage may shift with scale
failure_modes.real_world_case: Solar panel manufacturing - China had no initial advantage, but scale and learning curves created dominant position.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Learning curve > 15% per doubling indicates dynamic advantage

failure_modes.description: Focusing on absolute rather than comparative advantage
failure_modes.real_world_case: Doing everything yourself because you're good at it.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Do what you're relatively best at

failure_modes.description: Assuming advantages don't change
failure_modes.real_world_case: Relying on advantages that erode.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Comparative advantages change over time

failure_modes.description: Advantage in area that doesn't matter
failure_modes.real_world_case: Best at feature customers don't value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Advantage must be in valued dimension

failure_modes.description: Too narrow focus on comparative advantage
failure_modes.real_world_case: Single skill becoming obsolete.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Don't over-specialize

models.name: Marginal Utility/Diminishing Returns
models.description: Each additional unit provides less satisfaction than the previous one.

failure_modes.name: Diminishing Returns Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing diminishing marginal utility
failure_modes.example_scenario: Continuing to add features when marginal utility to customers is near zero

failure_modes.name: Average vs Marginal Confusion
failure_modes.description: Confusing average utility with marginal utility
failure_modes.example_scenario: Expanding production because average profit is good when marginal profit is negative

failure_modes.name: Utility Function Misspecification
failure_modes.description: Incorrectly specifying what creates utility
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming customers value features when they actually value simplicity

failure_modes.name: Interpersonal Utility Comparison
failure_modes.description: Incorrectly comparing utility across different people
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming all customers have same utility function when preferences vary widely

failure_modes.name: Negative Marginal Utility Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing when marginal utility becomes negative
failure_modes.example_scenario: Adding more information to report when it actually reduces usefulness

failure_modes.description: Not accounting for diminishing returns
failure_modes.real_world_case: WeWork's expansion - assumed each new location added same value, missed diminishing returns in saturated markets.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Marginal return < 50% of average indicates saturation

failure_modes.description: Utility depends on starting point, not absolute level
failure_modes.real_world_case: Salary negotiations - $100K feels different going from $80K vs $120K, same absolute amount.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Losses weighted ~2x gains in most decisions

failure_modes.description: Using average costs/benefits when marginal matters
failure_modes.real_world_case: Airline pricing - average cost per seat is high, but marginal cost of filling empty seat is near zero.
safeguards: Price to marginal cost in competitive markets
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Marginal cost < 30% of average indicates high fixed cost business

failure_modes.description: Utility of one thing depends on others
failure_modes.real_world_case: Smartphone without apps - hardware utility depends on software ecosystem, can't evaluate independently.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Complementarity multiplier can exceed 3x standalone value

failure_modes.description: Not accounting for how utility changes over time
failure_modes.real_world_case: Gym memberships - high utility imagined at signup, actual utility much lower due to adaptation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Projected vs actual utility diverges > 50% for most subscriptions

safeguards: Price to marginal cost in competitive markets

models.name: Time Value of Money
models.description: Money today is worth more than the same amount in the future.

models.name: Incentives & Incentive Alignment
models.description: People respond to incentives - ensure they are properly aligned.

failure_modes.name: Incentive Mapping Failure
failure_modes.description: Not mapping all relevant incentives in a situation
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyzing company without understanding management's personal incentives

failure_modes.name: Incentive Alignment Assumption
failure_modes.description: Assuming incentives are aligned when they're not
failure_modes.example_scenario: Trusting management recommendations without checking their incentives

failure_modes.name: Incentive Gaming Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not anticipating how incentives will be gamed
failure_modes.example_scenario: Setting sales targets without considering how they might be gamed

failure_modes.name: Non-Financial Incentive Neglect
failure_modes.description: Focusing only on financial incentives
failure_modes.example_scenario: Analyzing CEO behavior based only on compensation, missing empire-building motivation

failure_modes.name: Incentive Change Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing when incentives have changed
failure_modes.example_scenario: Expecting same behavior after compensation structure changed

failure_modes.name: Incentive Misalignment
failure_modes.description: Incentives not aligned with desired outcomes
failure_modes.example_scenario: Rewarding activity instead of results

failure_modes.name: Goodhart's Law
failure_modes.description: Metric becomes target and loses meaning
failure_modes.example_scenario: Optimizing metric while missing actual goal

failure_modes.name: Unintended Consequences
failure_modes.description: Incentives creating unintended behaviors
failure_modes.example_scenario: Incentive creating harmful side effects

failure_modes.name: Short-Term Incentive Bias
failure_modes.description: Incentives favoring short-term over long-term
failure_modes.example_scenario: Quarterly bonuses driving short-term thinking

failure_modes.name: Crowding Out Intrinsic Motivation
failure_modes.description: Extrinsic incentives destroying intrinsic motivation
failure_modes.example_scenario: Paying for activity that was previously done for love

failure_modes.description: When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure
failure_modes.real_world_case: Wells Fargo fake accounts - incentivized account openings, employees created millions of fake accounts.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Any metric weighted > 50% of compensation will be gamed

failure_modes.description: Extrinsic rewards can destroy intrinsic motivation
failure_modes.real_world_case: Blood donation studies - paying for blood reduced donations as it crowded out altruistic motivation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Extrinsic rewards can reduce intrinsic motivation by 25-50%

failure_modes.description: Incentives focused on short-term at expense of long-term
failure_modes.real_world_case: 2008 financial crisis - mortgage brokers incentivized on volume, not loan quality.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Incentive horizon should match value creation horizon

failure_modes.description: Agent's incentives differ from principal's interests
failure_modes.real_world_case: Real estate agents - incentivized to close quickly, not maximize price. Sell own homes for 3% more.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Agent incentive alignment < 80% indicates significant agency costs

failure_modes.description: Incentives create unintended behavioral changes
failure_modes.real_world_case: Cobra effect in India - bounty on cobras led to cobra farming, making problem worse.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Second-order effects can exceed first-order by 2-3x

models.name: Agency Problem/Principal-Agent Problem
models.description: Agents may not act in the best interest of principals they represent.

failure_modes.description: Agent incentives don't match principal goals
failure_modes.real_world_case: Fund managers churning for fees, not returns.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Agent should have 10%+ of wealth tied to principal outcomes

failure_modes.description: Agent uses superior information against principal
failure_modes.real_world_case: Real estate agents rushing sales for commission.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Agents spend 10x more time on own transactions

failure_modes.description: Agent takes risks because principal bears cost
failure_modes.real_world_case: Bank executives taking excessive risk with depositor money.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Agents should face 50%+ of downside they create

failure_modes.description: Attracting wrong type of agents
failure_modes.real_world_case: High commission structures attracting aggressive salespeople.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Incentive structure determines who you attract

failure_modes.description: Cost of oversight exceeds agency costs
failure_modes.real_world_case: Excessive compliance costs in regulated industries.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Monitoring costs should be < 10% of value at risk

models.name: Information Asymmetry
models.description: One party has more or better information than another in a transaction.

models.name: Adverse Selection
models.description: Bad participants drive out good ones when information is asymmetric.

failure_modes.description: Not recognizing information imbalance
failure_modes.real_world_case: Buying used car without knowing history.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Information asymmetry enables adverse selection

failure_modes.description: Adverse selection destroying market
failure_modes.real_world_case: Health insurance death spiral.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Adverse selection can destroy markets

failure_modes.description: Attracting wrong candidates
failure_modes.real_world_case: Low pay attracting low performers.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Compensation affects candidate pool

failure_modes.description: Attracting wrong partners
failure_modes.real_world_case: Desperate partners seeking deals.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Easy deals may have adverse selection

failure_modes.description: Policies that cause adverse selection
failure_modes.real_world_case: Pricing that drives away good customers.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Policies can create adverse selection

models.name: Moral Hazard
models.description: Behavior changes when insulated from risk or consequences.

failure_modes.description: Insurance creates incentive for risky behavior
failure_modes.real_world_case: Deposit insurance and S&L crisis - guaranteed deposits enabled risky lending.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Full insurance increases risk-taking by 30-50%

failure_modes.description: Implicit guarantees create systemic moral hazard
failure_modes.real_world_case: 2008 bank bailouts - expectation of rescue encouraged excessive risk.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: TBTF subsidy estimated at 0.5-0.8% funding cost advantage

failure_modes.description: Agents take risks with others' money
failure_modes.real_world_case: Hedge fund 2-and-20 - asymmetric payoff encourages excessive risk-taking.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Manager co-investment > 10% significantly reduces moral hazard

failure_modes.description: Behavior changes after contract signed
failure_modes.real_world_case: Health insurance - people with insurance may take fewer precautions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Healthcare utilization increases 30-40% with full coverage

failure_modes.mode: Moral hazard vs adverse selection confusion
failure_modes.description: Misdiagnosing which problem you have
failure_modes.real_world_case: Credit markets - high default rates could be adverse selection or moral hazard, different solutions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Correct diagnosis changes optimal policy by 50%+

failure_modes.description: Incentivizing risky behavior through protection
failure_modes.real_world_case: Bailout expectations encouraging risk.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Protection can encourage risk

failure_modes.description: Not seeing how incentives change behavior
failure_modes.real_world_case: Insurance leading to carelessness.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Protection changes behavior

failure_modes.description: Moral hazard at system level
failure_modes.real_world_case: Too big to fail banks.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Systemic moral hazard is most dangerous

failure_modes.description: Contracts creating perverse incentives
failure_modes.real_world_case: Cost-plus contracts encouraging waste.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Contract design affects behavior

failure_modes.description: Moral hazard spreading through system
failure_modes.real_world_case: Everyone taking risks because others are protected.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Moral hazard can spread

models.name: Pareto Principle (80/20 Rule)
models.description: Roughly 80% of effects come from 20% of causes.

failure_modes.description: Assuming 80/20 applies everywhere
failure_modes.real_world_case: Expecting 80/20 in uniform distributions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 80/20 is approximation, not law

failure_modes.description: Completely neglecting the long tail
failure_modes.real_world_case: Ignoring small customers entirely.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 80% still has value, just less per unit

failure_modes.description: Not recognizing the 20% changes
failure_modes.real_world_case: Focusing on yesterday's top customers.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: The vital few change over time

failure_modes.description: Not applying recursively
failure_modes.real_world_case: Not finding the 4% that drives 64%.
safeguards: Find the vital few of vital few

failure_modes.description: Using 80/20 to justify ignoring things
failure_modes.real_world_case: Neglecting important but not top priorities.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Prioritize, but don't completely neglect

safeguards: Find the vital few of vital few

models.name: Gresham's Law
models.description: Bad money drives out good; can apply broadly to quality degradation.

failure_modes.name: Bad Driving Out Good Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing when bad is driving out good
failure_modes.example_scenario: Not noticing that low-quality competitors are driving out quality players

failure_modes.name: Gresham Dynamics Timing
failure_modes.description: Misjudging speed of Gresham's Law dynamics
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming quality erosion will be gradual when it accelerates suddenly

failure_modes.name: Information Asymmetry Role
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing role of information asymmetry in Gresham dynamics
failure_modes.example_scenario: Quality products losing to inferior ones because customers can't tell difference

failure_modes.name: Gresham Reversal Opportunity
failure_modes.description: Missing opportunity to reverse Gresham dynamics
failure_modes.example_scenario: Not creating premium segment to escape race to bottom

failure_modes.name: Gresham in Non-Monetary Contexts
failure_modes.description: Not applying Gresham's Law to non-monetary situations
failure_modes.example_scenario: Missing that bad behavior is driving out good in organizational culture

models.name: Creative/Competitive Destruction
models.description: Innovation destroys old industries while creating new ones.

models.name: Value to a Private Owner
models.description: What would a rational private buyer pay for the entire business?

models.name: Mr. Market
models.description: The market is a manic-depressive partner offering prices daily - use it, don't be used by it.

models.name: Margin of Safety
models.description: Buy with a significant buffer between price and value to protect against errors.

failure_modes.description: Not enough buffer for uncertainty
failure_modes.real_world_case: Buying at fair value with no margin.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 20-30% margin minimum for uncertainty

failure_modes.description: Gradually reducing safety margins
failure_modes.real_world_case: Normalized deviance in safety standards.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Safety margins should never decrease

failure_modes.description: Precise calculations creating false confidence
failure_modes.real_world_case: DCF to two decimal places.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Add margin to precise calculations

failure_modes.description: Safety margin in area that doesn't matter
failure_modes.real_world_case: Over-engineering unimportant features.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Margin where it matters most

failure_modes.description: Racing to bottom removes safety
failure_modes.real_world_case: Airlines cutting maintenance to compete.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Some margins are non-negotiable

failure_modes.description: Gradually reducing safety margins
failure_modes.real_world_case: NASA Challenger - normalized deviance from safety standards.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Safety margins should never decrease

models.name: Tax Deferral & Compounding Advantage
models.description: Deferring taxes allows more capital to compound over time.

failure_modes.name: Compounding Underestimation
failure_modes.description: Underestimating the power of compounding over time
failure_modes.example_scenario: Preferring 10% one-time gain over 2% annual compounding

failure_modes.name: Negative Compounding Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing negative compounding effects
failure_modes.example_scenario: Ignoring small annual market share losses that compound to major decline

failure_modes.name: Compounding Interruption Risk
failure_modes.description: Not protecting compounding from interruption
failure_modes.example_scenario: Taking risks that could interrupt long-term compounding

failure_modes.name: Compounding Rate Sensitivity
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing sensitivity to compounding rate
failure_modes.example_scenario: Dismissing 1% fee difference that compounds to huge difference over time

failure_modes.name: Compounding Base Neglect
failure_modes.description: Focusing on rate while neglecting base
failure_modes.example_scenario: Chasing high return rate on small base vs lower rate on large base

failure_modes.description: Not grasping exponential growth
failure_modes.real_world_case: Underestimating long-term investment returns.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 7% annual = 2x in 10 years, 4x in 20 years

failure_modes.description: Not seeing how costs compound
failure_modes.real_world_case: 2% fees compounding to 50% of returns.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 1% fee = 25% less wealth over 30 years

failure_modes.description: Breaking the compound chain
failure_modes.real_world_case: Selling investments and restarting.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Each interruption costs years of compounding

failure_modes.description: Compounding the wrong thing
failure_modes.real_world_case: Growing revenue while profits shrink.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Compound profits, not just revenue

failure_modes.description: Bad habits compounding over time
failure_modes.real_world_case: Small daily inefficiencies becoming massive waste.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 1% daily decline = 97% annual decline

models.name: Value Creation vs. Value Capture
models.description: Creating value is different from capturing it - who keeps the surplus?

models.name: Obsolescence Risk
models.description: Business decay from innovation and changing technology.

models.name: Economic Moats
models.description: Durable competitive advantages that protect a business from competition.

failure_modes.description: Believing you have a moat when you don't
failure_modes.real_world_case: Groupon - thought they had network effects, actually had no moat. Competitors copied easily.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: True moat = ability to raise prices 10% without losing customers

failure_modes.description: Not recognizing moat is weakening
failure_modes.real_world_case: IBM mainframe moat - eroded over decades as computing shifted to PCs and cloud.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Margin decline > 2% annually indicates moat erosion

failure_modes.description: Relying on one moat source
failure_modes.real_world_case: Nokia's brand moat - strong brand wasn't enough when smartphone disruption hit.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Best businesses have 3+ moat sources

failure_modes.description: Sacrificing moat for growth
failure_modes.real_world_case: Luxury brands licensing - short-term revenue but dilutes brand moat.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Growth that reduces ROIC by > 5% is moat-destructive

failure_modes.description: Moats dependent on regulation can disappear
failure_modes.real_world_case: Taxi medallion collapse - Uber showed regulatory moats can be disrupted.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Regulatory moats have 20-year half-life on average

models.name: Cost Advantages
models.description: Structural low-cost position that competitors cannot easily replicate.

failure_modes.description: Cost advantage declining
failure_modes.real_world_case: Competitors achieving similar costs.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Cost advantages erode over time

failure_modes.description: Cost focus missing value opportunities
failure_modes.real_world_case: Cutting costs that customers value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Some costs create value

failure_modes.description: Losing scale that drives cost advantage
failure_modes.real_world_case: Market share loss increasing unit costs.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Scale-based cost advantages need volume

failure_modes.description: Competitors copying cost structure
failure_modes.real_world_case: Process innovations being copied.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Cost advantages can be copied

failure_modes.description: Cost advantage not sustainable
failure_modes.real_world_case: Labor cost advantage disappearing.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Ensure cost advantages are sustainable

models.name: Differentiation & Brand Power
models.description: Unique products or strong brands that command premium pricing.

models.name: Switching Costs
models.description: Costs that make it difficult for customers to change suppliers.

failure_modes.name: Switching Cost Overestimation
failure_modes.description: Overestimating customer switching costs
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming customers are locked in when they're actually switching to competitors

failure_modes.name: Switching Cost Erosion
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing erosion of switching costs over time
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming data migration costs will persist when tools make migration easy

failure_modes.name: Switching Cost Type Confusion
failure_modes.description: Not distinguishing between different types of switching costs
failure_modes.example_scenario: Treating financial and learning switching costs the same when they behave differently

failure_modes.name: Switching Cost Asymmetry
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing asymmetric switching costs
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming switching costs work both ways when it's easier to switch out than in

failure_modes.name: Switching Cost vs Value Confusion
failure_modes.description: Confusing switching costs with genuine value creation
failure_modes.example_scenario: Interpreting low churn as customer satisfaction when it's actually high switching costs

failure_modes.description: Assuming customers are more locked in than they are
failure_modes.real_world_case: Blackberry enterprise - thought switching costs were high, iPhone made switching worthwhile.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Switching costs must exceed 20% of annual value to be effective

failure_modes.description: Customers resent lock-in and leave when possible
failure_modes.real_world_case: Cable TV bundles - forced bundling created resentment, customers fled to streaming.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: NPS < 0 with high switching costs indicates resentment

failure_modes.description: New technology reduces switching costs
failure_modes.real_world_case: Bank account switching - fintech APIs made switching much easier.

failure_modes.description: Confusing lock-in with customer value

failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Usage declining while retention stable = switching cost dependence

failure_modes.description: Switching costs declining

failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Switching costs can erode

failure_modes.description: Customers resenting lock-in

failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Artificial switching costs create resentment

failure_modes.description: Thinking switching costs are higher than they are
failure_modes.real_world_case: Customers switching despite perceived barriers.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Test actual switching costs

failure_modes.description: Relying on switching costs instead of value
failure_modes.real_world_case: Product quality declining while relying on lock-in.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Switching costs don't replace value

failure_modes.description: Competitors reducing your switching costs
failure_modes.real_world_case: Competitor offering migration tools.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Competitors attack switching costs

models.name: Network Effects
models.description: Value increases as more users join the network.

failure_modes.name: Network Effect Existence Assumption
failure_modes.description: Assuming network effects exist when they don't
failure_modes.example_scenario: Claiming network effects for product where user value doesn't increase with more users

failure_modes.name: Network Effect Strength Overestimation
failure_modes.description: Overestimating the strength of network effects
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming winner-take-all when users easily multi-home across platforms

failure_modes.name: Negative Network Effects Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing negative network effects
failure_modes.example_scenario: Not recognizing that more users degrade experience through congestion or spam

failure_modes.name: Network Effect Timing
failure_modes.description: Misjudging when network effects kick in or plateau
failure_modes.example_scenario: Expecting immediate network effects when critical mass hasn't been reached

failure_modes.name: Local vs Global Network Effects
failure_modes.description: Confusing local and global network effects
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming global network effects for marketplace that's actually local

failure_modes.description: Claiming network effects without evidence
failure_modes.real_world_case: Many 'social' apps - claimed network effects but users didn't actually benefit from others joining.
warning_signs: No clear user benefit from growth
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: True network effects show engagement increasing with user count

failure_modes.description: More users actually decrease value
failure_modes.real_world_case: Exclusive clubs - value comes from exclusivity, more members reduces value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Negative effects emerge when congestion > capacity * 0.8

failure_modes.description: Network effects may be local, not global
failure_modes.real_world_case: Uber - network effects are city-level, not global. Each city is separate battle.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Local network effects require 30%+ share per market

failure_modes.description: Can't get either side without the other
failure_modes.real_world_case: Many failed marketplaces - couldn't solve cold start problem.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Need critical mass of ~1000 active users per side typically

failure_modes.description: Users on multiple networks reduce lock-in
failure_modes.real_world_case: Drivers on Uber and Lyft - multi-homing reduces network effect moat.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Multi-homing > 30% significantly weakens network effects

models.name: Scale Economies - Supply Side

models.name: Scale Economies - Demand Side
models.description: More users create more value for all users.

models.description: Costs fall with cumulative production as efficiency improves.

models.description: Physical distribution networks create barriers to entry.

models.description: Markets where the leader captures disproportionate value.

models.name: Moat Durability
models.description: How long the competitive advantage will last.

models.name: Industry Structure

models.description: Some industries compete rationally; others destroy value through price wars.

models.description: Two-sided markets connecting different user groups.

models.description: Overcapacity destroys returns; disciplined supply maintains pricing.

models.description: Riding strong secular trends for sustained growth.

models.name: Technology as Friend vs. Killer

failure_modes.name: Scale Economies Overestimation
failure_modes.description: Overestimating the magnitude of scale economies
failure_modes.example_scenario: Projecting 50% cost reduction from scale when industry shows 20%

failure_modes.name: Diseconomies of Scale Blindness
failure_modes.description: Not recognizing diseconomies that emerge at large scale
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming bigger is always better without considering bureaucracy costs

failure_modes.name: Scale Timing Misjudgment
failure_modes.description: Misjudging how quickly scale economies can be achieved
failure_modes.example_scenario: Expecting immediate cost benefits from acquisition when integration takes years

failure_modes.name: Scale Source Confusion
failure_modes.description: Not understanding the source of scale economies
failure_modes.example_scenario: Assuming scale benefits from volume when they actually come from scope

failure_modes.name: Minimum Efficient Scale Misjudgment
failure_modes.description: Misjudging the minimum efficient scale for an industry
failure_modes.example_scenario: Entering market at scale below minimum efficient scale

failure_modes.description: Assuming scale always helps, missing when it hurts
failure_modes.real_world_case: GM vs Toyota - GM's massive scale created bureaucracy and inflexibility that Toyota's leaner operation beat.
safeguards: Track per-unit costs at each scale
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Coordination costs > 15% of revenue indicates diseconomies

failure_modes.description: Expanding into unrelated areas thinking scale benefits transfer
failure_modes.real_world_case: GE's conglomerate strategy - assumed management scale economies, but diversification destroyed value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Unrelated diversification destroys value 60%+ of time

failure_modes.description: Not recognizing when scale benefits plateau
failure_modes.real_world_case: Craft beer vs Budweiser - beyond certain scale, beer production costs flatten, allowing craft to compete.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Cost reduction < 5% per doubling indicates MES reached

failure_modes.description: Growing without improving processes
failure_modes.real_world_case: Theranos - scaled operations without actually developing working technology.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Unit economics must improve with scale, not just volume

failure_modes.description: Scale achieved through few large customers creates fragility
failure_modes.real_world_case: GT Advanced Technologies - scaled for Apple sapphire contract, bankruptcy when Apple cancelled.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: No single customer > 15% of revenue for stability

safeguards: Track per-unit costs at each scale

models.name: Cancer-Surgery Formula
